Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I sat at my desk, the clock ticking closer to the project deadline. As a mentor, I’d spent hours preparing a structured session for my team, determined to share the skills they’d need to succeed. My notes were organized, examples ready, and I could almost see the relief on their faces when I’d help them untangle the project’s toughest knots. But my phone buzzed—another shift as a telemarketer. The new service we were selling was complicated, and today, prospects were relentless. They fired off technical questions the script barely touched. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection smoothly, to keep the calls moving, but I felt exposed, improvising answers I wasn’t sure about. My mind kept drifting to my team, waiting for guidance, while my headset tethered me to a world of quotas and call times. The pressure built inside me, torn between being the reliable mentor my team needed and the quick-thinking telemarketer my boss demanded. I stared at my notes, then at the blinking phone, heart pounding, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
